results.name: Denominator of 2*n*A000111(n-1)/A000111(n): approximations of Pi using Euler (up/down) numbers.
comment: The rationals r(n)=2*n*e(n-1)/e(n), where e(n)=A000111(n), approximate Pi as n -> oo. - _M. F. Hasler_, Apr 03 2013
See the Delahaye reference and a link by W. Lang given in A132049.
Apply the Akiyama-Tanigawa transform (or algorithm) to A046978(n+2)/A016116(n+1):
For numerators of Balmer0(n) see A076109, A000265 and A061037(n-1) (End).
Other completely unrelated rational approximations of Pi are given by A063674/A063673 and other references there. - _M. F. Hasler_, Apr 03 2013
formula: a(n)=denominator(r(n)) with the rationals r(n):=2*n*e(n-1)/e(n) where e(n):=A000111(n).
mathematica: e[n_] := If[EvenQ[n], Abs[EulerE[n]], Abs[(2^(n + 1)*(2^(n + 1) - 1)*BernoulliB[n + 1])/(n + 1)]]; r[n_] := 2*n*(e[n - 1]/e[n]); a[n_] := Denominator[r[n]]; Table[a[n], {n, 1, 23}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Mar 26 2013 *)
xref: Cf. triangle A008281 (main diagonal give zig-zag numbers A000111).
